Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Community-Based Aid Responses to Refugee Crises

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the 1990s, the United Nations has increasingly acknowledged the prolonged nature of refugee crises, and the need for humanitarian solutions that not only offer emergency relief to refugees but also address their long-term needs. Accordingly, it has called for a new "Community-Based Approach" to humanitarian aid, which integrates refugees in their neighboring countries through welfare programs and infrastructural support. The Syrian refugee crisis, however, throws this new approach in grave doubt. The sheer scale of civilian displacement, now reaching 4.3 million people, makes integration immeasurably difficult for countries neighboring Syria. With the mass exodus of refugees, it is now vital to understand how the refugee crisis is being managed in asylum countries. This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous empirically-grounded scientific fieldwork, explores how humanitarian organizations negotiate the challenges of community-based aid programs in response to refugee crises.

Malay Firoz, under the supervision of Dr. Catherine Lutz of Brown University, will examine how humanitarian organizations implement community-based aid programs in Jordan and Lebanon. As small developing countries, both Jordan and Lebanon are struggling to cope with the sudden influx of refugees, and their governments are anxious to prevent refugees from integrating. However, while the relatively stable Jordanian government has strictly regulated its borders and contained refugees in camps, domestic turmoil has prevented the Lebanese government from doing the same. The two countries therefore provide ideal locations for comparing how humanitarian organizations frame their official roles and responsibilities in different political contexts, how aid workers on the ground adopt or transform these framings in the course of everyday aid work, and what refugees expect from humanitarian organizations. In order to pursue these questions, the researcher will conduct twelve months of ethnographic fieldwork based in Amman and Beirut. He will employ a mixed-methods approach, including textual analysis of policy statements and institutional charters, semi-structured interviews with UN officials, aid workers and refugees, as well as participant observation in humanitarian field offices and refugee camps. The comparative findings from this research will provide insight into the effectiveness of community-based aid programs amidst large-scale displacement, and help humanitarian policy-makers design programs specifically suited to different contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Malay Firoz (co-PI), under the supervision of Dr. Catherine Lutz (PI), conducted a comparative ethnographic study of community-based humanitarian aid programs for Syrian refugees in Jordan and Lebanon. Over the course of 17 months between 2015 and 2017, Firoz conducted a total of 276 interviews with United Nations agencies, humanitarian donors, international NGOs, local and regional NGOs, government ministries and refugees. Through these interviews, Firoz charted an important transformation in humanitarian policy taking place in the context of the Syrian refugee crisis.

 

Traditional humanitarian policy thinking mandates a sharp distinction between humanitarian and development interventions, and advocates a gradual progression from the former to the latter as a crisis evolves from an emergency into a protracted socioeconomic problem. However, with the number of protracted crises growing around the world, the UN has been forced to reevaluate this model, and the Syrian refugee crisis has presented a particularly important occasion to reconfigure policy approaches. There are several reasons for this. For one, according to Firoz's interlocutors, the sheer scale of the Syrian refugee crisis has rendered traditional emergency relief-based efforts financially unsustainable in the long run. For another, the fact that both Jordan and Lebanon are middle-income countries, with established institutions and infrastructure on which a predominantly urban refugee population already depends. This presents policymakers with a unique opportunity to channel large-scale developmental aid into bolstering those institutions and infrastructures, with the presumption that building the “resilience” of host communities in this manner also makes refugees’ presence more sustainable. In other words, there is a growing recognition that the job of humanitarians is not simply to restore baseline standards of living. Just as war and displacement irrevocably change societies, so too can humanitarianism use crises as opportunities to raise the baseline and transform countries for the better.

 

Despite its promises, however, this resilience approach has garnered mixed responses from the humanitarian sector. Veterans in the field argue that the humanitarian industry is not structured to facilitate a seamless institutional merger of humanitarian and developmental prerogatives, and different UN agencies have frequently clashed with one another over jurisdiction and funding. International NGOs are also worried that the shift towards developmentalism will come at the expense of core emergency needs, that it will increasingly channel humanitarian funding to host governments, while simultaneously tasking NGOs with quasi-governmental responsibilities they are not equipped to handle. But perhaps the most troubling aspect for NGOs is the political implication of calling humanitarian aid development. As the former president of an international NGO told Firoz, development is normatively a contract between states and citizens, and the provision of aid to host states without granting refugees rights of nationality cannot be called development. To do so privileges the priorities of host at the expense of refugees, which is especially problematic at a time when states across Europe and the Middle East are closing their borders in violation of international norms governing refugee protection. Further, the steady incorporation of humanitarian prerogatives into the developmental machinery of host governments can potentially compromise the founding principle of humanitarian actors to operate neutrally in conflict zones, and may impact their capacity to negotiate independently on behalf of refugees.

 

These ongoing debates are rarely reported in the media, but the way they play out and the settlements that are reached will have a major impact on the responses of states and global governance institutions to emerging crises. By going beyond formal policy statements to document the thoughts and opinions of aid workers across different specializations and nationalities, Firoz's project offers an in-depth view of internal critiques and contestations within the humanitarian industry. Anthropology has long problematised the presumption of humanitarian and development organizations to be “apolitical” by pointing to the political consequences of their programs and the political contexts in which they are enmeshed. While this critique is well taken, it often paints the world of policy in overly broad strokes, as if policymakers are all homogenously "ungrounded" and uniformly guilty of the same mistakes. Firoz's project, on the other hand, advances the anthropology of humanitarianism beyond "outsider" critiques of policy. Rather than "exposing" the limits of policy, this project explores how humanitarian actors fold a practice of self-critique into their work, and what forms of power and powerlessness they exercise when confronting the limits of their interventions.
